moves.1. e4 e5 2. Ne2: This is the Alapin Opening which is an alternative to Nf3. The knight develops so as to prevent the Bg4 pin and allowing f4.
moves.3. d4: Aggresive move striking the hold that Black has on the center
moves.4. Ng3: ? Trades off knights but doubling his pawns
moves.4... Nxg3 5. hxg3 Nc6: Defends his e5 pawn and attacks the d4 pawn.
moves.6. Nc3: ? Again, this invites Black to kill the d4 pawn with a gain of tempo.
moves.6... exd4 7. Nd5: White is in trouble here, 2 pawns down after only 7 moves.
moves.7... Be7: Simple development and the bishop can be captured.
moves.8... g6: Defends agains this... even better is 8.O-O 9.Bh6 Bf6 then all is covered (thanks nuntar for the comment)
moves.9... f5: Opens up his position while he is behind in development, unwise.
moves.10. Rxh7: Sacrifices his rook here. If 10.Rxh7 11.Qxg6+ Kf8 12.Nf6 Rg7 13.Nh7+ Rxh7 14. Qg8++
moves.13. Rxh8+: Closing in on the Black King.
moves.15. Rxf8#:
The end....perhaps Black should have played d6 earlier and focused more on development before playing f5.

Hope you enjoyed it.
